body_text.text: Internet-based search engine data have been widely used in various fields, including infectious diseases epidemic prediction. This manuscript aimed to extend the literature by exploring the feasibility of using Baidu search data to monitor and predict the cases of HIV/AIDS, syphilis and gonorrhea in mainland China. The data analysis method of this research has innovation, and the results have certain enlightenment for AIDS prevention and control. This is a well designed and carefully implemented study and the findings are of interest to related researchers or public health workers. A few major and minor concerns are listed below. 1. There are seasonal fluctuations in HIV/AIDS, syphilis and gonorrhea cases in Figure 1 . Please add the possible reasons in the discussion section.

2. There are some typos in the article that need to be corrected. 3 . Is there a lack of "ethical description" in the method section? 4. In the article, the description of the number of cases had appeared as "HIV/AIDS cases", "the incidence of HIV/AIDS", "notified incident case counts" and "reported incident case counts", please modify it to be consistent.
Taavi Erkkola UNAIDS, Strategic Information department,Switzerland REVIEW RETURNED 17-Jan-2020

The manuscript is well written, describing the process, the methodology, and its rationale very clearly and precisely enough for replication by others. One of the purposes of this study was to enable prediction of infections, and "help health facilities...make preemptive and preventative treatment plans." However, as the study presents only national level data, it would not be cost effective for all regions/facilities to be acting on the basis of national dataset. It would be important that the authors expand on explaining the availability of the search index and diagnosis data by sub-national locations, and the potential applicability of that to the health authorities/actors in those locations. This would make the utility of this research and data more meaningful and purposeful, as set out in the rationale for the study. The only part where I noted a need for language correction was on page 6, starting row 48: "These positive results...". The sentence needs to be properly edited in English.

To reviewer #1, Junjie Xu: Many thanks for your comments and suggestion. The major advice you put forward is for the validation of vector autoregressive (VAR) model and the need to update the data. We consider we should describe the applicability of the model and the seasonal fluctuation in detail based on your comments. In addition, the reason why we did not update the data and the prediction is shown as follows:

Q1: The VAR model is suitable for the analysis of multivariate time series. "Our results expanded the application range of VAR in epidemiology (VAR model is more widely used in economics)". Is there a similar literature for applying VAR to the analysis of infectious diseases? How to verify the accuracy of applying this analysis method? A1: The vector autoregressive (VAR) model is one of the extensions of time series analysis. Time series analysis models have been broadly applied in the area of surveillance and prediction of infectious diseases. For example, generalized additive model (GAM) and time-series method were applied to analyze the association between hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) cases in children aged <15 years and meteorological variables in Guangzhou from 2008 to 20111. In addition, multivariate infectious disease surveillance have also been used for various infectious diseases because it could be applicable by adding other variables into the model2 3. For VAR model in infectious diseases, it was mostly used in spatiotemporal distribution or test-incidence feedback4 5. Existing literature used time series analysis and multivariate models to explore the applicability of VAR model. We applied these models in our analyses and got good prediction result (the performance of prediction results was evaluated by metrics Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) etc.). A2 & A3: We appreciate the reviewer's suggestion. The prediction was calculated using not only official data but search engine data. We found the algorithm of the Baidu search volume for specific keywords have experienced an update, rendering the search data in 2016-2017 to be different from those in 2018-2019. There is an improvement of the search engine statistics in Baidu, thus future research could be done to adjust or change models accordingly. In our future research we will try to add other search or browsing history from different social websites to the data set to make the prediction more valid and then complete our prediction method. Because of above reasons, we think it would be better to stick to data obtained in 2016-2017.

Q4: The mathematical model of vector autoregressive (VAR) model failed to include the parameter of annual HIV anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage in China, it is well know that it has substantial influence to future new reported HIV/AIDS cases.

A4: Unfortunately the ART-related words were not included in the keywords set of Baidu search engine, which forbids us from getting data on the search volume by typing highly relevant keywords referred by the reviewer. However, we did use similar words to replace such as 'HIV treatment' in Chinese to explore the relationship between search condition and confirmed diagnoses. Q2: There are some typos in the article that need to be corrected. A2: Thank you for your suggestion and we have revised the incorrect typos accordingly.

Q3: Is there a lack of "ethical description" in the method section? A3: Thanks for your reminding and we have added the following wording in the manuscript. No work with human subjects was directly involved in our research. The search data were recorded from Baidu Search Index Website (http://index.baidu.com/v2/index.html#/) and the official diagnosed cases were extracted from Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (China CDC) monthly reports or academic journal Chinese journal of AIDS&STD. No data ''involved any personal information. Permission to conduct the research was granted by School of Public Health, Sun Yat-sen University (2019008).

Q4: In the article, the description of the number of cases had appeared as "HIV/AIDS cases", "the incidence of HIV/AIDS", "notified incident case counts" and "reported incident case counts", please modify it to be consistent.
A4: Thank you for your suggestion and we have unified the wording into the ''newly diagnosed cases of HIV/AIDS, syphilis and gonorrhea.''
To reviewer #2, Taavi Erkkola: Thank you for your high evaluation of our work. Our answers are as follows.

Q1: However, as the study presents only national level data, it would not be cost effective for all regions/facilities to be acting on the basis of national dataset. It would be important that the authors expand on explaining the availability of the search index and diagnosis data by sub-national locations, and the potential applicability of that to the health authorities/actors in those locations. This would make the utility of this research and data more meaningful and purposeful, as set out in the rationale for the study. A1: We appreciate the reviewer's constructive suggestion. It would be more precise to zoom into data at provincial or even lower levels. Albeit Baidu Index website at both national and provincial levels are accessible, the disease report system at provincial level is both untimely and inconsistent. In many provinces, only aggregated figures are reported on a yearly basis, monthly reports are not available. This makes it impossible for us to compare Baidu search data and disease report data reported at provincial level. This however points to the necessity of timely and consistent disease reporting system at provincial and lower levels. We added this sentence in the Discussion.
Q2: The only part where I noted a need for language correction was on page 6, starting row 48: "These positive results...". The sentence needs to be properly edited in English.
A2: Thanks for your revision and we have edited this sentence.

FIGREF0.text: Q2: The author used Baidu search engine index and related parameters to predict new reported HIV/AIDS cases, while it only calculated the prediction performance with validation data from November 2016 to October 2017, the prediction span is related short and not included the conditions during 2018 to 2019. Q3: Since the number of Baidu search data is highly correlated with the HIV/AIDS reported cases, it is interesting to predict the number of HIV/STDs cases in the year 2020 and 2021.

FIGREF1.text: There are seasonal fluctuations in HIV/AIDS, syphilis and gonorrhea cases in Figure 1. Please add the possible reasons in the discussion section. A1: The seasonal fluctuation changed and circled according to the festivals and AIDS-relevant events. The sentences described the phenomena and explained the possible reason of seasonal fluctuations in paragraph 2, discussion part: 'Figure 2 depicted there were seasonal periodicity for all three HIV/STD, dropping abruptly from January to February which may attribute to the testing intention reduction of people during the Spring Festival, then going up from February and after several waves tending to be stable in December except of the cases of HIV/AIDS possibly due to the testing promotion activities during the World AIDS Day'.

The abstract takes into consideration the requested changes and now has its clear merits for being published.

Minor revisions: Q1: Please revise points #1 and #2 in the 'Strengths and limitations' section of your manuscript (after the abstract) so that they are presented as clear strengths or limitations of your study that relate directly to the methods. A1: We removed the original #2 which was not directly related to the method in this manuscript and revised #1 to focus on the prediction performance and data structure of the model we used.Q2: Please work to improve the quality of the English throughout your manuscript. We recommend asking a native English speaking colleague to assist you or to enlist the help of a professional copyediting service.
